SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including those that allude to significant characters found in mythology (e.g., Herculean).
Content: Read the sentence from line 6 of Passage 1.
:box:Whoever can a͟c͟c͟o͟m͟p͟l͟i͟s͟h this task will have the farm.
As it is used in the sentence, what word has almost the same meaning as a͟c͟c͟o͟m͟p͟l͟i͟s͟h?

A.Choice: complete

B.Choice: explain

C.Choice: share

D.Choice: watch

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: Read line 13 from Passage 1.
:box:KURT: I have no good ideas. I must not get discouraged though, or I will never win the farm. I have to keep thinking.
What does line 13 MOSTLY show about Kurt?

A.Choice: He is giving.

B.Choice: He is skillful.

C.Choice: He is truthful.

D.Choice: He is hopeful.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
In Passage 2, what is the MAIN problem the King tries to solve?

A.Choice: It takes too long to travel through his lands.

B.Choice: The roads are not fit for traveling.

C.Choice: His subjects do not amuse him.

D.Choice: He knows very few people.

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST supports the answer to the question above?

A.Choice: “'This is the swiftest carriage in all the land,' Sir Highfeather said proudly.”

B.Choice: “'Ohhh,' he groaned. 'What a great reward I would give to anyone who could shorten my journey.'”

C.Choice: “The bridges were in ruins, their planks ripped apart and their ropes whipping in the wind.”

D.Choice: “A small story it was, but so funny that the king laughed and asked for another.”

SubTopics: Compare and contrast the point of view from which different stories are narrate,d including the difference between first- and third-person narratives.
Content: From whose point of view is Passage 2 told?

A.Choice: The passage is told in first person by a narrator.

B.Choice: The passage is told in third person by the king.

C.Choice: The passage is told in third person by a narrator.

D.Choice: The passage is told in first person by the king.

SubTopics: Explain major differences between poems, drama, and prose, and refer to the structural elements of poems (e.g., verse, rhythm, meter) and drama (e.g., casts of characters, settings, descriptions, dialogue, stage directions) when writing or speaking about a text.
Content: In what way is Passage 1 told differently than Passage 2?

A.Choice: Passage 1 has stage directions.

B.Choice: Passage 1 is written using rhyme.

C.Choice: Passage 1 has several characters.

D.Choice: Passage 1 is written using only dialogue.

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast the treatment of similar themes and topics (e.g., opposition of good and evil) and patterns of events (e.g., the quest) in stories, myths, and traditional literature from different cultures.
Content: How do the main characters in BOTH passages solve problems in a similar way?

A.Choice: They think of smart ways to fix the problems.

B.Choice: They use their strength to fix the problems.

C.Choice: They work as a team to fix the problems.

D.Choice: They ask for help to fix the problems.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence BEST tells a theme from BOTH passages?

A.Choice: The most important things in life are rewards and riches.

B.Choice: The person who works the hardest will win every time.

C.Choice: The best idea can come from the least likely person.

D.Choice: The best way to succeed is to share with everyone.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Based on the passage, what is the reason Keisha does not read the book she is interested in?

A.Choice: She lost the book.

B.Choice: She left the book at school.

C.Choice: The library does not have the book.

D.Choice: Her mother will not get her the book.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including those that allude to significant characters found in mythology (e.g., Herculean).
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 1.
:box:The librarian's last newsletter had explained that the library was s͟h͟o͟r͟t of funds this year.
Which example uses the word s͟h͟o͟r͟t the same way it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: I am sorry I was short with you when we spoke yesterday.

B.Choice: We are short of food for the campout.

C.Choice: That was a short vacation.

D.Choice: My uncle is a short man.

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Based on the passage, how does talking with her father change Keisha's feelings about the garage sale?

A.Choice: She becomes bored while cleaning her room.

B.Choice: She becomes comfortable with selling her toys.

C.Choice: She becomes amused by getting rid of presents.

D.Choice: She becomes upset when going through her toys.

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST supports the answer above?

A.Choice: “It was a rainy Saturday morning in May, and Keisha sat on the sofa looking out the window.”

B.Choice: “I want my toys!”

C.Choice: “There was Suzie, who was the thrilling surprise Keisha got for her fourth birthday.”

D.Choice: “Toys were meant to be played with.”

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: Based on the passage, which toy does Keisha value MOST?

A.Choice: Hippo

B.Choice: Callie

C.Choice: the stuffed giraffe

D.Choice: the stuffed giraffe

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Make connections between the text of a story or drama and a visual or oral presentation of the text, identifying where each version reflects specific descriptions and directions in the text.
Content: How does the picture BEST help the reader understand the passage?

A.Choice: It shows which toy Keisha wants to keep.

B.Choice: It shows that Keisha plans to sell many toys.

C.Choice: It shows why Keisha has decided to sell her toys.

D.Choice: It shows how Keisha will organize her toys for the sale.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast the point of view from which different stories are narrate,d including the difference between first- and third-person narratives.
Content: In the passage, who tells the story of Keisha and her toys?

A.Choice: Dad

B.Choice: Keisha

C.Choice: a narrator

D.Choice: the librarian

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
What is Passage 1 MAINLY about?

A.Choice: ways to live in tropical rain forests

B.Choice: how tropical rain forests are formed

C.Choice: where tropical rain forests are located

D.Choice: ways that tropical rain forests are special

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST supports the answer above?

A.Choice: “Rain forests are home to the greatest variety of plants and animals in the world.”

B.Choice: “It is hot and dark, and often wet, inside a rain forest.”

C.Choice: “Trees are the largest rain forest plants.”

D.Choice: “Today there are millions of people living in rain forests around the world.”

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Interpret information presented visually, orally, or quantitatively (e.g., in charts, graphs, diagrams, time lines, animations, or interactive elements on Web pages) and explain how the information contributes to an understanding of the text in which it appears.
Content: How do the picture and its labels support the information in Passage 1?

A.Choice: They show the parts of a rain forest.

B.Choice: They show insects that live in a rain forest.

C.Choice: They explain how the plants grow in a rain forest.

D.Choice: They explain how heat becomes trapped in a rain forest.

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: According to the part What Is the Weather Like? in Passage 1, what causes the water in the leaves to form into clouds?

A.Choice: The roots collect water from the ground.

B.Choice: The warmth of the air evaporates the water.

C.Choice: The rain clouds release water into the forest.

D.Choice: The water moves up the trunk from the roots.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which details from Passage 1 BEST support the idea that animals do important tasks in the rain forest? Select TWO answers.

A.Choice: “Some birds are fruit eaters, and some birds are seed eaters.”

B.Choice: “Some birds, like the nightjar, live on the ground.”

C.Choice: “Millions of tiny creatures such as insects and spiders live on the trees and in the undergrowth.”

D.Choice: “Termites help to clean the forest floor.”

E.Choice: “They help to spread pollen from flower to flower.”

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: According to paragraph 1 of Passage 2, what do all deserts have in common?

A.Choice: They are hot.

B.Choice: They are dry.

C.Choice: They are flat.

D.Choice: They are sandy.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.
Content: What is the meaning of the phrase s͟o͟a͟k͟ ͟u͟p in paragraph 2 of Passage 2?

A.Choice: catch

B.Choice: empty

C.Choice: take in

D.Choice: pour out

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: Read the sentences from paragraph 5 in Passage 2 below.
:box:Ocean currents chill the air, creating a thick fog blanket that traps moisture within it. So the land is arid—a desert.
How is the information in the sentences MAINLY presented?

A.Choice: by asking a question

B.Choice: by comparing and contrasting

C.Choice: by stating a problem and a solution

D.Choice: by making a cause-and-effect statement

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: Which sentence would be the BEST to add before sentence 1 to help the reader understand the passage?

A.Choice: The afternoon was coming to an end, and Anita and Karen were thinking about their other friends.

B.Choice: Anita and Karen were talking excitedly about their plan to go to the zoo.

C.Choice: Anita and Karen were hardly speaking to each other after another long argument.

D.Choice: It was a beautiful day, and Anita and Karen had spent it playing together.

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: How should the underlined word in sentence 5 be changed?

A.Choice: NO CHANGE

B.Choice: All of a sudden

C.Choice: Sooner or later

D.Choice: At the same time

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: Where should sentence 12 be moved to BEST organize the events in the passage?

A.Choice: NO CHANGE

B.Choice: after sentence 7

C.Choice: after sentence 9

D.Choice: after sentence 13

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: How should sentence 15 be changed?

A.Choice: NO CHANGE

B.Choice: “We sure have a lot of peaches,” this year Karen's mother said.

C.Choice: “We sure have a lot of peaches this year” Karen's mother said.

D.Choice: “We sure have a lot of peaches this year,” Karen's mother said.

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: What is the MOST LIKELY reason the writer uses the phrase “gentle squeeze” in sentence 17?

A.Choice: to suggest that Karen's mom is caring

B.Choice: to illustrate that Karen's mom is strict

C.Choice: to show that Karen's mom changes her mind quickly

D.Choice: to demonstrate that Karen's mom knows the work will be hard

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Which sentence should be added at the end of the passage to provide the best conclusion?

A.Choice: “I can't wait to tell her about our plan!”

B.Choice: “How will I explain my decision to her?”

C.Choice: “Maybe she wants to get started picking peaches right away.”

D.Choice: “When two best friends work together, they can solve any problem.”

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST supports the answer to the question above?

A.Choice: “she was eager to help her mother pick peaches”

B.Choice: “wondering what she should do”

C.Choice: “Karen was excited by her new idea.”

D.Choice: “just as the phone rang”

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
The writer wants to add a heading before sentence 5. Which heading would be best to add?

A.Choice: Music in Mexico

B.Choice: History of Mariachi

C.Choice: Bands Stay at Home

D.Choice: Learning Mariachi Music

Content: Which words from the passage BEST support the correct answer above?

A.Choice: “Meanwhile, other musical instruments provide a steady, forceful beat for the dancers.”

B.Choice: “The earliest bands played string instruments such as violins, guitars, and harps.”

C.Choice: “bands did not travel much.”

D.Choice: “festivals are held throughout the country.”

SubTopics: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.
Content: Read this sentence.
:box:𝟗. Instead, they would b͟e͟ ͟w͟i͟t͟h just the community.

A.Choice: entertain

B.Choice: help

C.Choice: interest

D.Choice: meet

Content: Read this sentence.
:box:𝟏𝟓. This music spread throughout Mexico and into the southwestern United States a͟l͟t͟h͟o͟u͟g͟h people heard it on radios and could buy recordings of it in stores.

A.Choice: because

B.Choice: but

C.Choice: earlier

D.Choice: unless

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: The writer is deciding whether sentence 18 belongs in the passage. Should the writer keep sentence 18?

A.Choice: Yes, because it tells about some musicians.

B.Choice: Yes, because it gives an example of one style of music.

C.Choice: No, because it does not support the topic of the passage.

D.Choice: No, because it repeats an idea from another part of the passage.

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Content: Read this sentence.
:box:𝟏𝟗. Some people even perform in mariachi bands as t͟h͟e͟r͟e jobs.
How should the underlined word in sentence 19 be changed?

A.Choice: theyr'e

B.Choice: their

C.Choice: thier

D.Choice: they're

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: What does the word t͟h͟r͟i͟v͟e MOST nearly mean as it is used in sentence 24?

A.Choice: to have speed

B.Choice: to have success

C.Choice: to have good health

D.Choice: to have big changes

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: Now read the writing task and draft a response. As you write, think about what makes your writing the best it can be.
problems/NMG4E/media/33a.jpg

:box:Imagine that this month, your school is celebrating art around the world. Classes are learning about the art people make. Students are making their own art. And this month, your school's newsletter will also be all about art!

You have just read three passages about making art.

Write an article for your school newsletter informing readers about different ways that art can be a part of people's lives. Use details from what you read about making art. Also use your own ideas and experiences with art as you write your article.

:ibox:Today you will be writing an informative text. When you write to inform, you

• share what you know about a topic with another person.
• think about what your reader may want to learn about the topic.
• put your information in an order that makes sense.
• use examples and details to make the information clear and interesting to your reader.

After you have read the passages, and before you begin writing, think about

• what you already know about artists and about making art yourself.
• why people enjoy making art.
• important things you learned by reading the passages.

Now write your response in the space provided.
